user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_TaskDelete:
```c
int32 OS_TaskDelete(osal_id_t task_id)
{
    int32                      return_code;
    OS_object_token_t          token;
    OS_task_internal_record_t *task;
    osal_task_entry            delete_hook;

    delete_hook = NULL;
    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, task_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        task = OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET(OS_task_table, token);

        /* Save the delete hook, as we do not want to call it while locked */
        delete_hook = task->delete_hook_pointer;

        return_code = OS_TaskDelete_Impl(&token);

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token);
    }

    /*
    ** Call the thread Delete hook if there is one.
    */
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS && delete_hook != NULL)
    {
        delete_hook();
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_TaskDelete:
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
OS_task_internal_record_t OS_task_table[LOCAL_NUM_OBJECTS]
...
#define OS_SUCCESS (0)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: The only function parameter of OS_TaskDelete is 'task_id'. In the body there is no assignment to task_id, no use of the address-of operator (&task_id), and task_id is passed by value to OS_ObjectIdGetById, so it cannot be modified by that call. Other pointers passed to functions (e.g., &token) refer to a local variable (token), not to a function parameter, so any modifications via those pointers would not violate Rule 17.8. The macro OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET and the calls OS_TaskDelete_Impl(&token) and OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token) operate on the local token, not on a parameter. The delete_hook usage and the delete_hook() call do not modify any function parameter. Therefore there are no fragments in this function that appear to modify a function parameter and none that need further investigation for compliance with MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
